Translated: 13.5. (in the case of the field - geographer) has been sung in various and varied stanzas by the Rishis, and also (so said) by the positions of the reasonably fixed rational Brahmsutra (i.e. by the indicative words of Brahma).

Original: 13.6 The great elements, egoism, intellect, and also the Unmanifested Nature, the ten senses and one (mind), and the five objects of the senses.
Translated: 13.6. Panch Mahabhut, ego, intelligence, nature, ten senses, one mind, five subjects of the senses.

Original: 13.7 Desire, hatred, pleasure, pain, the aggregate (the body), intelligence, fortitude  the field has thus been briefly described with its modifications.
Translated: 13.7. Desire, hatred, pleasure, sorrow, confusion (muscle), consciousness (consciousness of the inner mind) and nature - thus this field is summarized with disorders.

Original: 13.8 Humility, unpretentiousness, non-injury, forgiveness, uprightness, service of the teacher, purity, steadfastness, self-control.
Translated: 13.8. Immanence, indomitable, nonviolent, forgiving, earnest, service to the Acharya, purity, steadiness and self - control.

Original: 13.9 Indifference to the objects of the senses and also absence of egoism; perception of (or reflection on) the evil in birth, death, old age, sickness and pain.
Translated: 13.9. Irresponsibility towards the subject of the senses, lack of ego, birth, death, old age, disease and suffering.

Original: 13.10 Non-attachment, non-identification of the Self with son, wife, home and the rest, and constant even-mindedness on the attainment of the desirable and the undesirable.
Translated: 13.10. Asceticism and unviolence in sons, wives, houses, etc. and equality in the attainment of the desired and the unwanted.

Original: 13.11 Unswerving devotion unto Me by the Yoga of non-separation, resort to solitary places, distaste for the society of men.
Translated: 13.11. Unconditional devotion to me by exception; lonely living and a sense of community among the (uncultured) people.

Original: 13.12 Constancy in Self-knowledge, perception of the end of true knowledge  this is declared to be knowledge, and what is opposed to it is ignorance.
Translated: In spiritual knowledge, the philosophy of the soul, the form of permanence, or stability, is called knowledge, and the opposite is ignorance.

Original: 13.13 I will declare that which has to be known, knowing which one attains to immortality, the beginningless supreme Brahman, called neither being nor non-being.
Translated: 13.13 I will say that the conscious thing which man attains immortality by knowing is consciousness - the Anadhi, the Supreme Brahma, which can be neither true nor false.

Original: 13.14 With hands and feet everywhere, with eyes, heads and mouths everywhere, with ears everywhere, He exists in the worlds enveloping all.
Translated: 13.14. He is the hand and foot of all, the eye of all, the head and the mouth of all, the hearer of all, the one who is the universe.

Original: 13.15 Shining by the functions of all the senses, yet without the senses; unattached, yet supporting all; devoid of alities, yet their experiencer.
Translated: 13.15. He is the one who is enlightened by the virtues of all the senses, but is devoid of all the senses; he is the one who possesses all and devours virtues, even though he is without power and without virtues.

Original: 13.16 Without and within (all) beings the unmoving and also the moving; because of Its subtlety, unknowable; and near and far away is That.
Translated: 13. 16. (He is) situated within the ghost - mere; he is variable and astonished. He is unknowable by being subtle; he is distant and extremely near.

Original: 13.17 And undivided, yet It exists as if divided in beings; It is to be known as the supporter of being; It devours and It generates.
Translated: 13.17. And he is indivisible, yet he is situated like the divided in the ghosts. He is the infill, destroyer and originator of the Ghaiya Brahma ghost.

Original: 13.18 That, the Light of all lights, is said to be beyond darkness: knowledge, the knowable and the goal of knowledge, seated in the hearts of all.
Translated: 13. 18. (He is also called the light of lights and beyond darkness. He is the knowledge (in the form of consciousness) known and known by knowledge. He is located in the heart of all.

Original: 13.19 Thus the field, as well as knowledge and the knowable have been briefly stated. My devotee, knowing this, enters into My Being.
Translated: 13. 19. Thus, (by me) the field, knowledge and knowledge was called abbreviated. Knowing it from the essence (science) my devotee attains my form.

Original: 13.20 Know thou that Nature (matter) and the Spirit are both beginningless; and know also that all modifications and alities are born of Nature.
Translated: You know both nature and man are eternal, and you also know that all disorders and virtues are born of nature.

Original: 13.21 In the production of the effect and the cause, Nature (matter) is said to be the cause; in the experience of pleasure and pain, the soul is said to be the cause.
Translated: 13.21. Nature is called for the origin of action and cause and man is called for the vow of pleasure and sorrow.

Original: 13.22 The soul seated in Nature experiences the alities born of Nature; attachment to the alities is the cause of its birth in good and evil wombs.
Translated: 13.22. The man in nature has the qualities of nature which are the reason for his birth in the male 's good and bad vaginas.

Original: 13.23 The Supreme Soul in this body is also called the spectator, the permitter, the supporter, the enjoyer, the great Lord and the Supreme Self.
Translated: The supreme man is called in this body as Updraitya, Anumanatha, Bharta, Bhukta, Maheshvara and Paramahatma.

Original: 13.24 He who thus knows the Spirit and Matter together with the alities, in whatever condition he may be, he is not born again.
Translated: 13.24. Thus, a man who knows nature, including man and qualities, is not reborn even though he has lived (acted) in all manner.

Original: 13.25 Some by meditation behold the Self in the self by the self, others by the Yoga of knowledge, and still others by the Yoga of action.
Translated: 13. 25. Some men see the soul in the soul through the practice of meditation; others see the soul through the practice of sanksya yoga and some see the soul through the practice of sadak karmyoga.

Original: 13.26 Others also, not knowing thus, worship, having heard of It from others; they, too, cross beyond death, regarding what they have heard as the Supreme refuge.
Translated: But others who worship without knowing it, listening to others, those who listen to others, also deserve death.

Original: 13.27 Wherever a being is born, whether unmoving or moving, know thou, O best of the Bharatas (Arjuna), that it is from the union between the field and its knower.
Translated: 13. 27. O Bharat Shastra! Only know that whatever static moving object is produced, it is produced by the combination of the field and the field.

Original: 13.28 He sees, who sees the Supreme Lord, existing eally in all beings, the unperishing within the perishing.
Translated: 13. 28. The man who sees the immortal God in all mortal spirits is the one who sees (in reality).

Original: 13.29 Because he who sees the same Lord eally dwelling everywhere does not destroy the Self by the self; he goes to the highest goal.
Translated: Certainly, the man does not destroy the soul by the spirit of the same God who is everywhere equal, which gives him the ultimate speed.

Original: 13.30 He sees, who sees that all actions are performed by Nature alone and that the Self is actionless.
Translated: 13.30. The man who sees all the works done by nature and sees the soul as the maker, he sees.

Original: 13.31 When a man sees the whole variety of beings as resting in the One, and spreading forth from That alone, he then becomes Brahman.
Translated: 13. 31. This man receives Brahma when he sees the separate phases of ghosts in one (Paramath) and knows that it has expanded from him.

Original: 13.32 Being without beginning and being devoid of (any) alities, the Supreme Self, imperishable, though dwelling in the body, O Arjuna, neither acts nor is tainted.
Translated: O Kaunthai, this spirit is immortal because it is immortal and immortal. Although it is in the body, it does not work or bear fruit.

Original: 13.33 As the all-pervading ether is not tainted, because of its subtlety, so the Self seated everywhere in the body is not tainted.
Translated: 13. 33. Just as the universe is not absorbed by the microscopic nature of the sky, so the soul in the body is not absorbed everywhere.

Original:
13.34 Just as the one sun illumines the whole world, so also the Lord of the field (Supreme Self) 
illumines the whole field, O Arjuna.
Translated: 13.34 O India! Just as the sun shines on this whole people, so the same field shines on the whole region.

Original: 13.35 They who, by the eye of knowledge, perceive the distinction between the field and its knower and also the liberation from the Nature of being, go to the Supreme.
Translated: 13.35 Thus, those who know the distinction between the field and the field specialist through the male cognition and the salvation from the disorders of nature, attain the Supreme Brahma.

Original: 14.1 The Blessed Lord said  I will again declare (to thee) that supreme knowledge, the best of all knowledge, having known which all the sages have gone to the supreme perfection after this life.
Translated: 14.1. Shri Bhagwan said - I will repeat the best of all the knowledge, which all the people have passed through this (Lok) and have attained the ultimate Siddhi.

Original: 14.2 They who, having taken refuge in this knowledge, have attained to unity with Me, are neither born at the time of creation nor are they disturbed at the time of dissolution.
Translated: 14.2. Men who have taken refuge in this knowledge of my nature (Sardhayaam) do not be born in the beginning of creation and do not get distracted during the apocalypse.

Original: 14.3 My womb is the great Brahma; in that I place the germ; thence, O Arjuna, is the birth of all beings.
Translated: 14.3. O India, my great Brahmaputra is the Yoni of the ghosts in which I conceive; it is the origin of all the ghosts.

Original: 14.4 Whatever forms are produced, O Arjuna, in any womb whatsoever, the great Brahma is their womb and I am the seed-giving father.
Translated: 14.4. O Kaunthai, the vagina of all the idols that are born in the vagina is the womb of Mahābrahmā and I am the father of the seed.

Original: 14.5 Purity, passion and inertia  these alities, O Arjuna, born of Nature, bind fast in the body, the embodied, the indestructible.
Translated: 14.5. O Mahabah! Sutta, Raj and Tham are the three qualities of nature which bind the body soul with the body.

Original: 14.6 Of these, Sattva, which from its stainlessness is luminous and healthy, binds by attachment to happiness and by attachment to knowledge, O sinless one.
Translated: 14.6. O innocent Arjuna, in these (three), the essence is pure by being manifest and anonymous (harmless, unharmful or healing); (he binds the organism) to the addiction to pleasure and to the addiction to knowledge.

Original: 14.7 Know thou Rajas to be of the nature of passion, the source of thirst (for sensual enjoyment) and attachment; it binds fast, O Arjuna, the embodied one by attachment to action.
Translated: 14.7. O Kaunthai, know Rajaguna as ragash, which gives rise to thirst and attachment. It binds the bodily soul to the attachment of works.

Original: 14.8 But know thou Tamas to be born of ignorance, deluding all embodied beings; it binds fast, O Arjuna, by heedlessness, indolence and sleep.
Translated: 14.8. And O India, know that Tamoguna is born of ignorance, which seduces all the body - beings. It binds the soul by Pramad, laziness and sleep.

Original: 14.9 Sattva attaches to happiness, Rajas to action, O Arjuna, while Tamas verily shrouding knowledge attaches to heedlessness.
Translated: 14.9. O India, SattvaGuna makes happiness and Rajuguna work, but Thamoguna makes knowledge frequent and makes the soul pramaad.

Original: 14.10 Now Sattva arises (prevails), O Arjuna, having overpowered Rajas and Tamas; nor Rajas, having overpowered Sattva and Tamas; and now Tamas, having overpowered Sattva and Rajas.
Translated: 14.10. O India! Sometimes the state of Suttaga is increased by overwhelming Raj and Tham, sometimes the state of Tham is increased by overwhelming Raj and Tham, and sometimes the state of Rajguni is increased by overwhelming Tham and Tham.

Original: 14.11 When through every gate (sense) in this body, the wisdom-light shines, then it may be known that Sattva is predominant.
Translated: 14.11. When the knowledge - form of light is born in the gates of this body, all the senses, then know that the Sattvaga is increased.

Original: 14.12 Greed, activity, the undertaking of actions, restlessness, longing  these arise when Rajas is predominant, O Arjuna.
Translated: 14.12. O Bharat - Shreya, when Rajogun is raised, greed, inclination, the beginning of ordinary chests, lack of shame and spira, all of these are born.

Original: 14.13 Darkness, inertness, heedlessness and delusion  these arise when Tamas is predominant, O Arjuna.
Translated: 14.13. O Kurunandan, when Tamoguna is raised, there is unreason, inclination, Pramadh and Moha.

Original: 14.14 If the embodied one meets with death when Sattva is predominant, then he attains to the spotless worlds of the knowers of the Highest.
Translated: 14. 14. When this being (the body) receives death in the growth of the suttaga, then the Nirmala of the good doers, the heavenly worlds, is received.

Original: 14.15 Meeting death in Rajas, he is born among those who are attached to action; and dying in Tamas, he is born in the womb of the senseless.
Translated: 14.15. In the period of growth of the Rajaguna, after receiving death, he is born in the Karmasakti (man) Lok and in the period of growth of the Tamaguna (at death) he is born in the Murdhayoni.

Original: 14.16 The fruit of good action, they say, is Sattvic and pure, verily the fruit of Rajas is pain, and ignorance is the fruit of Tamas.
Translated: The fruit of good works is called satvical and nirmal; the fruit of raggona is pain and the fruit of tamoguna is ignorance.

Original: 14.17 From Sattva arises knowledge, and greed from Rajas; heedlessness and delusion arise from Tamas, and also ignorance.
Translated: 14.17. From Sattvagaun comes knowledge. From Rajogun comes greed and from Thamogun comes Pramadh, Moh and Ignorance.

Original: 14.18 Those who are seated in Sattva go upwards; the Rajasic dwell in the middle; and the Tamasic, abiding in the function of the lowest Guna, go downwards.
Translated: 14.18. Men in Sattupughu go upwards (to the people); Rajas men live in the middle (manush lok) and Tamas people in the very lowest trends of Thamogun go downwards.

Original: 14.19 When the seer beholds no agent other than the Gunas and knows That which is higher than they, he attains to My Being.
Translated: 14.19. When the seer man sees no other than the three qualities of the doer, i.e. does not understand and knows my element beyond the three qualities, then he attains my form.

Original: 14.20 The embodied one having crossed beyond these three Gunas out of which the body is evolved, is freed from birth, death, decay and pain, and attains to immortality.
Translated: 14.20. This body, through the origin of the male body, passes through the three qualities of birth, death, root and pain, and attains immortality.

Original: 14.21 Arjuna said  What are the marks of him who has transcended the three alities, O Lord? What is his conduct and how does he go beyond these three alities?
Translated: 14.21. Arjuna said - O Lord! What qualities does a man who has passed these three qualities possess? What kind of conduct does he have? And in what way does he pass these three qualities?

Original: 14.22 The Blessed Lord said  When light, activity and delusion are present, he hates them not, nor does he long for them when they are absent.
Translated: 14.22. Lord said, "O Pandas! (the wise man) does not hate them when they are attracted to light, tendency and temptation, nor does he desire them when they are retired.

Original: 14.23 He who, seated like one unconcerned, is not moved by the alities, and who, knowing that the alities are active, is self-centred and moves not.
Translated: 14.23. who is as indifferent as he is and cannot be distracted by qualities and who remains in a position knowing that "the qualities behave themselves" and is not distracted by that position.

Original: 14.24 Who is the same in pleasure and pain, who dwells in the Self, to whom a clod of earth, stone and gold are alike, who is the same to the dear and the unfriendly, who is firm, and to whom censure and praise are as one.
Translated: 14.24. who is healthy, who is united in happiness and sorrow, and who has a good eye for clay, stone and gold; such a brave man considers the beloved and the unloved as equals the reproach and the self - praise.

Original: 14.25 Who is the same in honour and dishonour, the same to friend and foe, abandoning all undertakings  he is said to have transcended the alities.
Translated: 14.25. Such initiation which is equal in honour and disgrace, even in favour of enemy and friend, is called masculine qualitative.

Original: 14.26 And he who serves Me with unswerving devotion, he, crossing beyond the alities, is fit for becoming Brahman.
Translated: 14.26. The man who worships Me through the devotion of the unfaithful becomes a Brahma by passing these three qualities.

Original: 14.27 For I am the abode of Brahman, the immortal and the immutable, of everlasting Dharma and of absolute bliss.
Translated: 14.27. For I am the reputation of Amrut, Avya, Brahma, Eternal Religion and Unanthic, that is, Paramartha happiness.

Original: 15.1 The Blessed Lord said  They (the wise) speak of the indestructible peepul tree having its root above and branches below, whose leaves are the metres or hymns: he who knows it is a knower of the Vedas.
Translated: 15.1. Shri Bhagwan said -- (The wise man calls this world tree) the upper root and lower branch Ashvatha and Avya; whose leaves are Vedas, the one who knows such is Vedat.

Original: 15.2 Below and above spread its branches, nourished by the Gunas; sense-objects are its buds; and below, in the world of men, stretch forth the roots, originating action.
Translated: 15.2. The branches of that tree are extended upwards and downwards by virtue; (Pich) the subject is its shoots; its other roots following the works in the man - folk extend downwards.

Original: 15.3 Its form is not perceived here as such, neither its end nor its origin, nor its foundation nor resting place: having cut asunder this firmly rooted peepul tree with the strong axe of non-attachment.
Translated: 15.3. The nature of this tree as it is said is not available here, because it has no beginning and no end and no prestige.

Original: 15.4 Then That goal should be sought for, whither having gone none returns again. I seek refuge in that Primeval Purusha Whence streamed forth the ancient activity or energy.
Translated: 15.4. (Then) We should explore the position which men attained do not return to the re-world. "I am the refuge of the first man from whom this ancient tendency is transmitted".

Original: 15.5 Free from pride and delusion, victorious over the evil of attachment, dwelling constantly in the Self, their desires having completely turned away, freed from the pairs of opposites known as pleasure and pain, the undeluded reach the eternal goal.
Translated: 15.5. Those who have retired their dignity and charm, who have conquered the stigma, who are spiritually situated, whose desires have retired and who have been freed from the conflicts called happiness - sorrow, such unconventional sages attain that unconscious position.

Original: 15.6 Neither doth the sun illumine there nor the moon, nor the fire; having gone thither they return not; that is My supreme abode.
Translated: 15.6. The sun, the moon, or the fire cannot illuminate it.

Original: 15.7 An eternal portion of Myself having become a living soul in the world of life, draws to (itself) the (five) senses with the mind for the sixth, abiding in Nature.
Translated: 15.7. In this life - society, there is a perpetual part of me that is a living being. It draws to itself the five senses and minds that are in nature (at the time of death).

Original: 15.8 When the Lord (as the individual soul) obtains a body and when He leaves it, He takes these and goes (with them) as the wind takes the scents from their seats (flowers, etc.).
Translated: 15.8. When the God (of the body) moves (from one body), he takes these (the senses and minds) and carries them to another body as the smell carries air from the sanctuary of the breath.

Original: 15.9 Presiding over the ear, the eye, touch, taste and smell, as well as the mind, it enjoys the objects of the senses.
Translated: 15.9. (This organism) consumes subjects by sheltering these senses and minds, i.e. the ear, eye, touch, nose and nose.

Original: 15.10 The deluded do not see Him Who departs, stays and enjoys; but they who possess the eye of knowledge behold Him.
Translated: 15.10. The spirit, which is harmonized with qualities, is not seen by fools, abandoning the body, inhabiting it or experiencing it; (but) men of knowledge see it.

Original: 15.11 The Yogins striving (for perfection) behold Him dwelling in the Self; but, the unrefined and unintelligent, even though striving, see Him not.
Translated: 15.11. Yogis see the soul in their heart as they strive, whereas those with an unrealistic and unconscious mind do not see it even as they strive.

Original: 15.12 That light which residing in the sun illumines the whole world, that which is in the moon and in the fire  know that light to be Mine.
Translated: 15.12. You know the glory of the bright sun that is in the sun and illuminates the whole world and the bright moon that is in the fire.

Original: 15.13 Permeating the earth I support all beings by (My) energy; and having become the watery moon I nourish all herbs.
Translated: 15.13. I myself enter the earth and take possession of the ghost with my os and become the moon in the form of juice to nourish all the medicines, i.e. plants.

Original: 15.14 Having become the fire Vaisvanara, I abide in the body of living beings and, associated with the Prana and the Apana, digest the fourfold food.
Translated: 15.14. I myself digest four kinds of food, which are soul and apane, in the universal fire, which is in the bodies of all living beings.

Original: 15.15 And I am seated in the hearts of all; from Me are memory and knowledge, as well as their absence. I am verily That which has to be known by all the Vedas; I am indeed the author of the Vedanta and the knower of the Vedas am I.
Translated: 15.15. I am the heart of all living beings. I have memory, knowledge and knowledge. I am the only known object through all the Vedas and I am the only one who knows the Vedas and the Vedas.

Original:
15.16 Two Purushas there are in this world, the perishable and the imperishable. All beings are 
the perishable and the Kutastha  the unchanging  is called the imperishable.
Translated: 15.16. In this folk, the Ksar and the Aksar are two males, all the ghosts are the Ksar and are called the Kutastha Aksar.

Original: 15.17 But distinct is the Supreme Purusha called the highest Self, the indestructible Lord Who, pervading the three worlds, sustains them.
Translated: But the best man is another, called the Divine Spirit, who is the invisible God who enters and holds all the three worlds.

Original: 15.18 As I transcend the perishable and am even higher than the imperishable, I am declared to be the highest Purusha in the world and in the Vedas.
Translated: 15.18. Because I am past the QS and superior to the letters, I am known as Pursothamma in the Lok and the Vedas.

Original: 15.19 He who, undeluded, knows Me thus as the highest Purusha, he, knowing all, worships Me with his whole being (heart), O Arjuna.
Translated: 15.19. O India! Thus, whoever, without acknowledgement, knows man me manothatma, is all knowing and devote himself to me with all his heart.

Original: 15.20 Thus, this most secret science has been taught by Me, O sinless one; on knowing this, a man becomes wise, and all his duties are accomplished, O Arjuna.
Translated: 15.20. O innocent India! Thus this secret scripture is said by me, knowing it makes man wise and capable.

Original: 16.1 The Blessed Lord said  Fearlessness, purity of heart, steadfastness in knowledge and Yoga, almsgiving, control of the senses, sacrifice, study of scriptures, austerity and straightforwardness.
Translated: 16.1. Shri Lord said - Abhay, purity of heart, firm position in the Jnana Yoga, charity, Dham, Yajna, Swadya, Tapas and Arjuna.

Original: 16.2 Harmlessness, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peacefulness, absence of crookedness, compassion towards beings, non-covetousness, gentleness, modesty, absence of fickleness.
Translated: 16.2. Nonviolence, truth, absence of anger, renunciation, peace, apashunam (not to condemn anyone), compassion for the ghost, compassion, compassion, shame, and unconditional.

Original: 16.3 Vigour, forgiveness, fortitude, purity, absence of hatred, absence of pride  these belong to the one born for a divine state, O Arjuna.
Translated: 16.3. O India! The lack of speed, forgiveness, patience, cleanliness, pride and pride are all the characteristics of a man who has attained divine wealth.

Original: 16.4 Hypocrisy, arrogance and self-conceit, anger and also harshness and ignorance, belong to one who is born for a demoniacal state, O Partha (Arjuna).
Translated: O Parth, pride, pride, pride, anger, harsh words and ignorance are all inheritance.

Original: 16.5 The divine nature is deemed conducive to liberation, and the demoniacal to bondage. Grieve not, O Arjuna, thou art born with divine endowments.
Translated: O Pandavas, do not grieve for the divine heritage has been granted for salvation and for the Asuri heritage bond.

Original: 16.6 There are two types of beings in this world, the divine and the demoniacal; the divine has been described at length; hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the demoniacal.
Translated: O Parth, there are two kinds of ghosts in this folk, the divine and the Asuri. In them the nature of the gods is described in detail; now the nature of the Asurians is width: listen to me.

Original: 16.7 The demoniacal know not what to do and what to refrain from; neither purity, nor right conduct nor truth is found in them.
Translated: 16.7. People of a humble nature have no tendency; they have no knowledge of retirement; they have no purity, no virtue, no truth.

Original: 16.8 They say, "This universe is without truth, without (moral) basis, without a God, brought about by mutual union, with lust for its cause; what else?"
Translated: 16.8. They say that this world is without shelter, false and godless, it is born of inter-sex sexual relations, and what can be the cause?

Original: 16.9 Holding this view, these ruined souls of small intellect and fierce deeds, come forth as the enemies of the world for its destruction.
Translated: 16.9. People with a low intelligence and a strong will to destroy, who adopt this vision, are born as enemies of the world (unwanted ones) to destroy it.

Original: 16.10 Filled with insatiable desires, full of hypocrisy, pride and arrogance, holding evil ideas through delusion, they work with impure resolves.
Translated: 16.10. These people of unclean resolutions act in the world by adopting false notions, seeking refuge in never-fulfilled desires of ambition, value and substance.

Original: 16.11 Giving themselves over to immeasurable cares ending only with death, regarding gratification of lust as their highest aim, and feeling sure that that is all.
Translated: 16.11. These Asuri people, who are suffering from endless anxieties that last until death and who consider poison consumption the ultimate goal, are convinced that "this is it".

Original: 16.12 Bound by a hundred ties of hope, given over to lust and anger, they strive to obtain by unlawful means hoards to wealth for sensual enjoyments.
Translated: 16.12. In the grip of work and anger, bound by hundreds of hopes, they strive to accumulate unjustly wealth to satisfy their subjects.

Original: 16.13 "This has been gained by me today; this desire of mine I shall fuffil; this is mine and this wealth also shall be mine in future."
Translated: 16.13. I have found this today and will also obtain this manor, I have this much wealth and will have even more wealth in the future.

Original: 16.14 "That enemy has been slain by me; and others also I shall slay. I am the lord. I enjoy. I am perfect, powerful and happy."
Translated: 16.14. "This enemy is killed by me and I will kill other enemies as well", "I am God and the Savior", "I am a perfect man", "I am strong and happy".

Original: 16.15 "I am rich and born in a noble family. Who else is equal to me? I shall perform sacrifices. I shall give (charity). I shall rejoice," thus deluded by ignorance.
Translated: 16.15. "I was born in a wealthy and noble family. Who else is like me?", 'I will sacrifice', 'I will give', 'I will celebrate' - they are fascinated by this kind of ignorance.

Original: 16.16 Bewildered by many a fancy, entangled in the snare of delusion, addicted to the gratification of lust, they fall into a foul hell.
Translated: 16.16 They are confused in many ways, trapped in snares and obsessions, and fall into a deep, unclean hell.

Original: 16.17 Self-conceited, stubborn, filled with the pride and intoxication of wealth, they perform sacrifices in name out of ostentation, contrary to scriptural ordinances.
Translated: 16.17. Those who consider themselves superior, astonished, possessed of wealth and honour, do not have the law of the law but do so by the mere nominal sacrifices.

Original: 16.18 Given over to egoism, power, haughtiness, lust and anger, these malicious people hate Me in their own bodies and in those of others.
Translated: 16.18. Selfish, forceful, mirrored, work and anger-induced, prostrating, these are haters of the self in the body and of others.

Original: 16.19 Those cruel haters, worst among men in the world, I hurl those evil-doers into the wombs of demons only.
Translated: I repeatedly bring down such abusive, cruel and abusive people into the world, which is to say, I bring them into the world.

Original: 16.20 Entering into demoniacal wombs and deluded, birth after birth, not attaining Me, they thus fall, O Arjuna, into a condition still lower than that.
Translated: 16.20. O Kaunthai! They get the assurious vagina in the birth of a foolish man and (thus) they get the untimely rate without me.

Original: 16.21 Triple is the gate of this hell, destructive of the self  lust, anger and greed; therefore one should abandon these three.
Translated: 16.21. Work, anger and greed are the three doors of self - destruction, so these three must be abandoned.

Original: 16.22 A man who is liberated from these three gates to darkness, O Arjuna, practises what is good for him and thus goes to the Supreme Goal.
Translated: O Kaunthai, the man freed from these three gates of hell conducts his means of well - being and thus attains the Para - speed.

Original: 16.23 He who, having cast aside the ordinances of the scriptures, acts under the impulse of desire, attains not perfection, nor happiness nor the Supreme Goal.
Translated: 16.23. A man who abandons the law and acts only by his own desire does not attain perfection, neither happiness nor perfection.

Original: 16.24 Therefore, let the scripture be thy authority in determining what ought to be done and what ought not to be done. Having known what is said in the ordinance of the scriptures, thou shouldst act here in this world.
Translated: 16.24. Therefore, the scriptures are proof for you in the law of duty and duty. You should know the scriptures and do your deeds.

Original: 17.1 Arjuna said  Those who, setting aside the ordinances of the scriptures, perform sacrifice with faith, what is their condition, O Krishna? Is is Sattva, Rajas or Tamas?
Translated: 17.1. Arjuna said -- O Krishna! What is the status of those who abandon the Sanskrit and worship with devotion? Is it Satviq or Rajasik or Tamasik?

Original: 17.2 The Blessed Lord said  Threefold is the faith of the embodied, which is inherent in their nature  the Sattvic (pure), the Rajasic (passionate) and the Tamasic (dark). Do thou hear of it.
Translated: 17.2. Shri Bhagwan said -- that natural (ignorant) devotion of the body - bearing men is of three kinds - satvical, rajsical and tamsical, you listen to me.

Original: 17.3 The faith of each is in accordance with his nature, O Arjuna. The man consists of his faith; as a man's faith is, so is he.
Translated: 17.3. O India, the devotion of all men is in accordance with their Sattva (nature, sacrament). This man is devout, therefore the man who is devout is the same as himself, that is, his devotion is the same as his.

Original: 17.4 The Sattvic or the pure men worship the gods; the Rajasic or the passionate worship the Yakshas and the Rakshasas; the others (the Tamasic or the deluded people) worship the ghosts and the hosts of the nature-spirits.
Translated: 17.4. Satviqi men worship the gods and Rajas people worship the Yaksha and demons, and other Tamsi Jan Ghosts and demons.

Original: 17.5 Those men who practise terrific austerities not enjoined by the scriptures, given to hypocrisy and egoism, impelled by the force of lust and attachment.
Translated: 17.5. Those who practice the fast without the law and who are also engaged in ambition, ego, work and rage.

Original: 17.6 Senseless, torturing all the elements in the body and Me also, Who dwell in the body,  know thou these to be of demonical resolves.
Translated: And you are certain of the foolish people who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who are the ones who

Original: 17.7 The food also which is dear to each is threefold, as also sacrifice, austerity and almsgiving. Hear thou the distinction of these.
Translated: There are three kinds of food that everyone loves. So there are three kinds of sacrifice, fasting and charity.

Original: 17.8 The foods which increase life, purity, strength, health, joy and cheerfulness (good appetite), which are savoury and oleaginous, substantial and agreeable, are dear to the Sattvic (pure) people.
Translated: 17.8. The seven men are fond of a steady and pleasing diet, i.e. food, which promotes age, satiety, strength, health, happiness and love and is juicy, smooth, smooth, and pleasing to the mind.

Original: 17.9 The foods that are bitter, sour, saline, excessively hot, pungent, dry and burning, are liked by the Rajasic and are productive of pain, grief and disease.
Translated: 17.9. Bitter, sour, salty, overheated, spicy (bitter, peppery), bitter. Inflammatory, painful, sad and disease - causing foodstuffs Rajas are dear to man.

Original: 17.10 That which is state, tasteless, putrid, rotten, refuse and impure, is the food liked by the Tamasic.
Translated: Semi - ripe, non - juicy, odorless, spicy, spicy and unclean food is loved by the Tamsi people.

Original: 17.11 That sacrifice which is offered by men without desire for reward as enjoined by the ordinance (scripture), with a firm faith that to do so is a duty, is Sattvic or pure.
Translated: 17.11. The Yajna which is controlled by the Sanskrit and which is done by those who do not have the desire for a certain result of such a mind - solution is Yajna Satviq.

Original: 17.12 The sacrifice which is offered, O Arjuna, seeking a reward and for ostentation, know thou that to be a Rajasic Yajna.
Translated: O Bharatheshre Arjuna, consider this Yajna as a Rajas, which is done for the sake of Damb and the desire for fruit.

Original: 17.13 They declare that sacrifice to be Tamasic which is contrary to the ordinances of the scriptures, in which no food is distributed, which is devoid of Mantras, gifts and faith.
Translated: 17.13. Yajna without scripture, without food, without mantras, without southern and without devotion is called tamas - yadna.

Original: 17.14 Worship of the gods, the twice-born, the teachers and the wise, purity, straightforwardness, celibacy and non-injury are called the austerities of the body.
Translated: 17.14. The worship of the Devas, Dvijas (Brahmanas), Guru and sage, the Shauch, Arjuna (Simple), Brahmacharya and Ahimsa, is called bodily Taap.

Original: 17.15 Speech which causes no excitement, truthful, pleasant and beneficial, the practice of the study of the Vedas, are called austerity of speech.
Translated: 17.15. A sentence which is not irritating, which is lovely, beneficial and true and the Swadhayya practice of the Vedas is called Vangiya (Vani) Tap.

Original: 17.16 Serenity of mind, good-heartedness, self-control, purity of nature  this is called mental austerity.
Translated: The happiness of mind, mildness, quiet self - control and purity of heart are all called manas - ta 'bah.

Original: 17.17 This threefold austerity, practised by steadfast men, with the utmost faith, desiring no reward, they call Sattvic.
Translated: 17.17. The aforementioned trivial Tapas performed with the highest reverence by men who have no desire for fruit are called Satvics.

Original: 17.18 The austerity which is practised with the object of gaining good reception, honour and worship, and with hypocrisy, is here said to be Rajasic, unstable and transitory.
Translated: 17.18. The uncertain and transient Tapas which is done for worship, honor and worship or only by the Damb (Pakhand) is here called Rajas.

Original: 17.19 That austerity which is practised out of a foolish notion, with self-torture, or for the purpose of destroying another, is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 17.19. The act of ta'bah which is foolishly done for the purpose of self - suffering or the destruction of others is called ta'bah tamas.

Original: 17.20 That gift which is given to one who does nothing in return, knowing it to be a duty to give in a fit place and time to a worthy person, that gift is held to be Sattvic.
Translated: 17.20. "It is duty to give" - In this sense, a donation given to a qualified person who is not expected to be rewarded by the country or time of giving is considered to be a satvical donation.

Original: 17.21 And, that gift which is given with a view to receive something in return, or looking for a reward, or reluctantly, is held to be Rajasic.
Translated: 17.21. And any donation made with the intention of giving or with the desire for fruit is considered a donation.

Original: 17.22 The gift that is given at a wrong place and time, to unworthy persons, without respect or with insult is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 17.22. Donations given to the poor without hospitality or disdain in an unfit country are considered donations.

Original: 17.23 "Om Tat Sat": This has been declared to be the triple designation of Brahman. By that were created formerly, the Brahmanas, the Vedas and the sacrifices.
Translated: 17.23. 'Unu, Tha Sath' is called the Trivial Direction (Name) of Brahma; from it in the Adithya (Pura) Brahman, Vedas and Yajna were created.

Original: 17.24 Therefore, with the utterance of "Om" are the acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity as enjoined in the scriptures, always begun by the students of Brahman.
Translated: 17.24. Therefore, the rituals of Yajna, Dhana and Tapas in the Brahmin scriptures always begin with the pronunciation of Onkar.

Original: 17.25 Uttering ï1Tatï1, without aiming at the fruits, are the acts of sacrifice and austerity and the various acts of gifts performed by the seekers of liberation.
Translated: 17.25. Pronouncing the word 'Tath', without desire for fruit, Mukmukshūjan performs various rituals such as Yajna, Tapas, Dhana etc.

Original: 17.26 The word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of reality and of goodness; and so also, O Arjuna, the word ï1Satï1 is used in the sense of an auspicious act.
Translated: O Parth, the word Sat is used in Satyabhushan and Sadhūva, and the word Sat is used in Prashast (Shirth, Good) Karmas.

Original: 17.27 Steadfastness in sacrifice, austerity and gift, is also called 'Sat' and also action in connection with these (or for the sake of the Supreme) is called 'Sat'.
Translated: A firm position in Yajna, Tapas and charity is also called Sath, and the deed done for it is also called Sath.

Original: 17.28 Whatever is sacrificed, given or performed, and whatever austerity is practised without faith, it is called 'Asat', O Arjuna; it is naught here or hereafter (after death).
Translated: O Parth! The sacrifice, charity, fasting and the deed which is done in disbelief is called asat; it is not profitable in this world nor after death.

Original: 18.1 Arjuna said  I desire to know severally, O mighty-armed, the essence or truth of renunciation, O Hrishikesa, as also of abandonment, O slayer of Kesi.
Translated: 18.1. Arjuna said - O Mahabah! O Hishikesh! O Keshinisudan! I want to know the essence of retirement and renunciation separately.

Original: 18.2 The Blessed Lord said  The sages understand Sannyasa to be the renunciation of action with desire; the wise declare the abandonment of the fruits of all actions as Tyaga.
Translated: 18.2. Shri Bhagavan said - (Some) poets consider the renunciation of the Jan Kamya karmas as "sania" and the thinkers call the renunciation of the fruits of all the karmas "abandon".

Original: 18.3 Some philosophers declare that actions should be abandoned as an evil; while others (declare) that acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be relinished.
Translated: 18.3. Some Manish people say that all works are sacrificial because they are defective; and others say that sacrifice, charity and taparup are not sacrificial.

Original: 18.4 Hear from Me the conclusion or the final truth about this abandonment, O best of the Bharatas; abandonment, verily, O best of men, has been declared to be of three kinds.
Translated: 18.4. O Bharathasattam, hear my judgment on this sacrifice. O Manshastra, it is said that there are three kinds of sacrifice.

Original: 18.5 Acts of sacrifice, gift and austerity should not be abandoned, but should be performed; sacrifice, gift and also austerity are the purifiers of the wise.
Translated: 18.5. Yajna, charity and Taparup Karma are not obligatory, but it is a duty; Yajna, charity and Tapar are the sanctifying of the Manishas.

Original: 18.6 But even these actions should be performed leaving aside attachment and the desire for rewards, O Arjuna; this is My certain and best conviction.
Translated: O Parth, these works too must be abandoned, without fruit and dependence, it is my determined best opinion.

Original: 18.7 Verily the renunciation of obligatory action is not proper; the abandonment of the same from delusion is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 18.7. It is not right to give up a fixed act; to give up a fixed act is called "Thomas renunciation".

Original: 18.8 He who abandons action on account of the fear of bodily trouble (because it is painful), does not obtain the merit of renunciation by doing such Rajasic renunciation.
Translated: 18.8. A man who gives up his work in pain for fear of physical suffering never receives the fruits of his sacrifice by making that royal sacrifice.

Original: 18.9 Whatever obligatory action is done, O Arjuna, merely because it ought to be done, abandoning attachment and also the desire for reward, that renunciation is regarded as Sattvic (pure).
Translated: 18.9. O Arjuna, the act of devotion, which is done by understanding "the duty to do", is considered the same as the act of devotion and devotion to fruits.

Original: 18.10 The man of renunciation, pervaded by purity, intelligent, and with his doubts cut asunder, does not hate a disagreeable work nor is he attached to an agreeable one.
Translated: 18.10. A man who does not hate unskilled work and is not obsessed with good work is a man of virtue, unshakable, intelligent and selfless.

Original: 18.11 Verily, it is not possible for an embodied being to abandon actions entirely; but he who relinishes the rewards of actions is verily called a man of renunciation.
Translated: 18.11. Since it is not possible for a man to give up the remaining deeds, the resulting sacrifice is called the sacrifice of man.

Original: 18.12 The threefold fruit of action (evil, good and mixed) accrues after death to the non-abandoners, but never to the abandoners.
Translated: 18.12. The good, bad and mixed fruits of the works are only obtained after death by the aggressors, but not by the saintly men.

Original: 18.13 Learn from Me, O mighty-armed Arjuna, these five causes as declared in the Sankhya system for the accomplishment of all actions.
Translated: O Mahabah! These five reasons for the accomplishment of all works are stated in statistical theory, which you know well from me.

Original: 18.14 The seat (body), the doer, the various senses, the different functions of various sorts, and the presiding deity, also, the fifth.
Translated: 18.14. The adhestan (body), the doer, the various incarnations (indriya) and the various and separate endeavors and the fifth is the deity.

Original: 18.15 Whatever action a man performs with his body, speech and mind  whether right or the reverse  these five are its causes.
Translated: 18.15. These are the five reasons why a man acts justly or unjustly with his body, speech and mind.

Original: 18.16 Now, such being the case, verily he who  owing to untrained understanding  looks upon his Self, which is isolated, as the agent, he of perverted intelligence, sees not.
Translated: 18.16. Now the man who, being an uneducated intellect, considers only the pure spirit as the doer, does not see the deformity man.

Original:
18.17 He who is free from the egoistic notion, whose intelligence is not tainted (by good or evil), 
though he slays these people, he slayeth not, nor is he bound (by the action).
Translated: 18.17. A man who has no sense of ego and no intellect, he does not actually die or commit sin even if he kills all these people.

Original: 18.18 Knowledge, the knowable and the knower form the threefold impulse to action; the organ, the action and the agent form the threefold basis of action.
Translated: 18.18. Knowledge, cognition and cognition are trivial karma inducers, and, karana, karana.

Original: 18.19 Knowledge, action and actor are declared in the science of the Gunas (Sankhya philosophy) to be of three kinds only, according to the distinction of the Gunas. Of these also, hear duly.
Translated: 18. 19. Knowledge, work and the doer are also called trivials in statistics by the secret of qualities; these too you should listen to me as well.

Original: 18.20 That by which one sees the one indestructible Reality in all beings, not separate in all the separate beings  know thou that knowledge to be Sattvic.
Translated: 18. 20. Knowledge by which man sees in all the separate spirits an indivisible and indestructible nature, you should know it.

Original: 18.21 But that knowledge which sees in all beings various entities of distinct kinds as different from one another  know thou that knowledge to be Rajasic.
Translated: 18.21. Knowledge by which man can distinguish the different feelings of all the spirits.

Original: 18.22 But that which clings to one single effect as if it were the whole, without reason, without foundation in Truth, and trivial  that is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 18.22. And the knowledge by which man becomes attached to a single act as if it were a complete thing. And what is aimless, without substance and narrow is knowledge.

Original: 18.23 An action which is ordained, which is free from attachment, and which is done without love or hatred by one who is not desirous of any reward  that action is declared to be Sattvic.
Translated: 18. 23. A deed which is determined and unconditional and done without any anger hatred by a man who does not want fruit is called a satvical deed.

Original: 18.24 But that action which is done by one longing for the fulfilment of desires or gain with egoism or with much effort  that is declared to be Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18.24. And the work which is done by a man who is very diligent and fruitful, egoistic, is called Karma Rajas.

Original: 18.25 That action which is undertaken from delusion, without a regard for the conseences, loss, injury and (one's own) ability  that is declared to be Tamasic (dark).
Translated: 18. 25. The work which is initiated only by mohabbas without considering the consequences, loss, violence and sarmatya (paurusum) is called karma tamas.

Original: 18.26 An agent who is free from attachment, non-egoistic, endowed with firmness and enthusiasm, and unaffected by success or failure, is called Sattvic (pure).
Translated: 18. 26. The person who is unconcerned, unconcerned, patient and enthusiastic and unfailing in the accomplishment and failure of the work is called the person who is the Satviq.

Original: 18.27 Passionate, desiring to obtain the reward of actions, greedy, cruel, impure, moved by joy and sorrow, such an agent is said to be Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18. 27. Raji, the carnal, greedy, violent, impure and haughty, is called the Karta Rajas.

Original: 18.28 Unsteady, vulgar, unbending, cheating, malicious, lazy, desponding and procrastinating  such an agent is called Tamasic.
Translated: 18. 28. Commissioner, nature, shock, stutter, natural, lazy, poisonous and long - strung is called Tamas.

Original: 18.29 Hear thou the threefold division of intellect and firmness according to the Gunas, as I declare them fully and distinctly, O Arjuna.
Translated: O Dhananjay, hear the trivial difference of wisdom and character, which is born of the virtues of infinity and separation.

Original: 18.30 The intellect which knows the path of work and renunciation, what ought to be done and what ought not to be done, fear and fearlessness, bondage and liberation  that intellect is Sattvic (pure), O Arjuna.
Translated: 18.30. O Parth, the wisdom that knows the principles of tendency and retirement, action and inaction, fear and fear and bond and salvation, is wisdom satviqui.

Original: 18.31 That, by which one wrongly understands Dharma and Adharma and also what ought to be done and what ought not to be done  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18.31 O Parth, the wisdom by which man does not know the truth of religion and iniquity, and duty and duty, is wisdom.

Original: 18.32 That, which, enveloped in darkness, sees Adharma as Dharma and all things perverted  that intellect, O Arjuna, is Tamasic (dark).
Translated: 18.32 O Parth, the wisdom surrounded by the Tamas which believes in iniquity and knows all things contrary to it is wisdom Tamashi.

Original: 18.33 The unwavering firmness by which, through Yoga, the functions of the mind, the life-force and the senses are restrained  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Sattvic (pure).
Translated: 18.33. is the Sattviqi.

Original: 18.34 But that, O Arjuna, by which, on account of attachment and desire for reward, one holds fast to Dharma (duty), enjoyment of pleasures and earning of wealth  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Rajasic (passionate).
Translated: 18.34 O earth son Arjuna, the man who desires to do karma is Dharma Rajsi, by which he possesses religion, meaning and work.

Original: 18.35 That, by which a stupid man does not abandon sleep, fear, grief, despair and also conceit  that firmness, O Arjuna, is Tamasic.
Translated: The concept by which the unwise man does not abandon dreams, fears, sorrows, ills and things is dharma tamsi.

Original: 18.36 And now hear from Me, O Arjuna, of the threefold pleasure, in which one rejoices by practice and surely comes to the end of pain.
Translated: 18.36 O Bharatheshastra, now hear me from the triple happiness in which (the sage man) enjoys by practice and attains the end of sorrows (where his sorrows end).

Original: 18.37 That which is like poison at first but in the end like nectar  that happiness is declared to be Sattvic, born of the purity of one's own mind due to Self-realisation.
Translated: 18.37 The first happiness which is like the poison (in the beginning) but is like the result of the amrit is called the happiness satvic, which arises from the offering of self - knowledge.

Original: 18.38 That happiness which arises from the contact of the sense-organs with the objects, which is at first like nectar, and in the end like poison  that is declared to be Rajasic.
Translated: 18. 38. The happiness which arises from the combination of the subjects and the senses is first like Amrit, but in the end is like poison, it is called Suk Rajas.

Original: 18.39 That happiness which at first as well as in the seel deludes the self, and which arises from sleep, indolence and heedlessness  that is declared to be Tamasic.
Translated: 18.39 The happiness which is seductive to the soul in the beginning and in the end is called the happiness tamas, which is the result of sleep, laziness and Pramadesh.

Original: 18.40 There is no being on earth or again in heaven among the gods, that is liberated from the three alities born of Nature.
Translated: 18. 40. There is no being on earth or among the gods of heaven that is free from these three qualities of nature.

Original: 18.41 Of Brahmanas, Kshatriyas and Vaisyas, as also of Sudras, O Arjuna, the duties are distributed according to the alities born of their own nature.
Translated: 18.41. O Parantapa, the Brahmins, the Kshatri, the Vaishya and the Shudras are divided according to the virtues of nature.

Original: 18.42 Serenity, self-restraint, austerity, purity, forgiveness and also uprightness, knowledge, realisation and belief in God are the duties of the Brahmanas, born of (their own) nature.
Translated: 18.42. Sham, Dham, Tapas, Swachh, Kshanthi, Arjuna, Wisdom, Science and Astiya - these are the natural deeds of Brahman.

Original: 18.43 Prowess, splendour, firmness, dexterity and also not fleeing from battle, generosity and lordliness are the duties of the Kshatriyas, born of (their own) nature.
Translated: 18.43. Bravery, speed, dharti, skill, non - flight from war, charity and god-feeling - these are all the natural acts of the Kshatriya.

Original: 18.44 Agriculture, cattle-rearing and trade are the duties of the Vaisya (merchant), born of (their own) nature; and action consisting of service is the duty of the Sudra (servant-class), born of (their own) nature.
Translated: 18. 44. Agriculture, cattle farming and commerce - these are the natural deeds of Vaishya, and the natural deeds of Shudra is to minister, i.e. to serve.

Original: 5.10 He who does actions, offering them to Brahman, and abandoning attachment, is not tainted by sin, just as a lotus-leaf is not tainted by water.
Translated: 5.10. A man who sacrifices all his deeds to Brahma and renounces asceticism is not bound to sin like a camel's leaf.

Original: 18.46 He from Whom all the beings have evolved and by Whom all this is pervaded  worshipping Him with his own duty, man attains perfection.
Translated: 18.46 The person attains his perfection by worshipping the Self - act of the One from whom the spirit - nature has its origin and through whom the whole world is encompassed.

Original: 18.47 Better is one's own duty (though) destitute of merits, than the duty of another well performed. He who does the duty ordained by his own nature incurs no sin.
Translated: 18.47. Self - religion without qualities is superior to a self - adherent religion. (Because man does not attain sin by doing the act prescribed by nature.

Original: 18.48 One should not abandon, O Arjuna, the duty to which one is born, though faulty; for, all undertakings are enveloped by evil, as fire by smoke.
Translated: O Kaunthai, even when you are defective, you should not abandon the natural action, for all actions are surrounded by defects, like fire from smoke.

Original: 18.49 He whose intellect is unattached everywhere, who has subdued his self, from whom desire has fled,  he by renunciation, attains the supreme state of freedom from action.
Translated: 18.49 The man with an omnipotent intellect who is spurious and vital attains the ultimate nirshkamya siddi by means of sannyas.

Original: 18.50 Learn from Me in brief, O Arjuna, how he who has attained perfection reaches Brahman (the Eternal), that supreme state of knowledge.
Translated: 18.50. How does a man who has achieved Siddha attain Brahma, and also the purity of knowledge, you will learn from me briefly.

Original: 18.51 Endowed with a pure intellect, controlling the self by firmness, relinishing sound and other objects and abandoning attraction and hatred.
Translated: 18.51 Be of sound mind, moderate in character, and reject the talk of words, and the hatred of anger.

Original: 18.52 Dwelling in solitude, eating but little, with speech, body and mind subdued, always engaged in meditation and concentration, resorting to dispassion.
Translated: 18.52. Vivikth Sevi, Lakhwashi (Mitahari) who has restrained his body, speech and mind, always prepared and committed to the practice of meditation.

Original: 18.53 Having abandoned egoism, strength, arrogance, desire, anger and covetousness, and free from the notion of 'mine' and peaceful,  he is fit for becoming Brahman.
Translated: 18.53 The ego, force, mirror, work, anger and ambition are forsaken and the man without mammatva and calm becomes worthy of attaining Brahma.

Original: 18.54 Becoming Brahman, serene in the Self, he neither grieves nor desires, the same to all beings, he obtains supreme devotion to Me.
Translated: 18.54 Brahmabhut (who has become a sadak brahma), a man of happy mind, who is not desirous or sad, receives my pra bhakti by being equal to all the ghosts.

Original: 18.55 By devotion he knows Me in truth, what and who I am; then having known Me in truth, he forthwith enters into the Supreme.
Translated: 18.55 By virtue of that piety he knows me, and what I am, and immediately after he knows me, he becomes a man.

Original: 18.56 Doing all actions always having taken refuge in Me, by My grace he obtains the eternal indestructible state of being.
Translated: 18.56. The man who always does all the works in a state of dependence, receives eternal, indomitable status from My Prasad (grace).

Original: 18.57 Mentally renouncing all actions in Me, having Me as the highest goal, resorting to the Yoga of discrimination do thou ever fix thy mind on Me.
Translated: 18.57. Be constantly persecuted by the sanctity of all works in me, by the sanctity of mind, by the sanctity of mind.

Original: 18.58 Fixing thy mind on Me, thou shalt by My grace overcome all obstacles; but if from egoism thou wilt not hear Me, thou shalt perish.
Translated: And if you do not hearken, you will be destroyed.

Original: 18.59 If, filled with egoism, thou thinkest: "I will not fight", vain is this, thy resolve; Nature will compel thee.
Translated: 18.59 And you who are arrogantly thinking, "I will not fight", that is your decision, a lie, because it is nature that will lead you.

Original: 18.60 O Arjuna, bound by thy own Karma (action) born of thy own nature, that which from delusion thou wishest not to do, even that thou shalt do helplessly.
Translated: O countrymen, you are bound by your natural ways, so that what you do not want to do you will be forced to do.

Original: 18.61 The Lord dwells in the hearts of all beings, O Arjuna, causing all beings, by His illusive power, to revolve as if mounted on a machine.
Translated: 18.61. O Arjuna, the God of all ghosts, who is on the machine, is in the heart of the ghost, who is in his majesty.

Original: 18.62 Fly unto Him for refuge with all thy being, O Arjuna; by His grace thou shalt obtain supreme peace (and) the eternal abode.
Translated: 18.62 O India, take refuge in Him with all your heart, and by His offering you will attain to the highest peace and eternal abode.

Original: 18.63 Thus has wisdom, more secret than secrecy itself, been declared unto thee by Me; having reflected over it fully, then act as thou wishest.
Translated: So I have told you, the most secret of all secrets, that after you have thought it over, you may do as you please.

Original: 18.64 Hear thou again My supreme word, most secret of all; because thou art dearly beloved of Me, I will tell thee what is good.
Translated: 18.64 Re: Once you hear from me the most secret word in all the caves. You are very dear to me, so I will tell you what is good for you.

Original: 18.65 Fix thy mind on Me, by devoted to Me, sacrifice to Me, bow down to Me. Thou shalt come even to Me; truly do I promise unto thee, (for) thou art dear to Me.
Translated: 18.65 Be thou honourable, pious, and serve me, and salute me; and ye shall receive me. This I promise you with truth, for ye are my beloved.

Original: 18.66 Abandoning all duties, take refuge in Me alone: I will liberate thee from all sins; grieve not.
Translated: 18.66. Leave all religions and come to my refuge, I will deliver you from all sins, do not grieve.

Original: 18.67 This is never to be spoken by thee to one who is devoid of austerities or devotion, nor to one who does not render service or who does not desire to listen, nor to one who cavils at Me.
Translated: 18.67. This knowledge should not be said to a man who is ungrateful, nor to an ungodly, nor to a man who is ungrateful, nor to a man who is ungrateful, or who is a reproach to me, that is, who sees fault in me.

Original: 18.68 He who with supreme devotion to Me will teach this supreme secret to My devotees, shall doubtlessly come to Me.
Translated: 18.68 The man who teaches this secret knowledge to my devotees with the highest love for me is certainly the one who receives it.

Original: 18.69 Nor is there any among men who does dearer service to Me, nor shall there be another on earth dearer to Me than he.
Translated: 18.69 There is no man amongst men who does my most dear work, nor will there be anyone on earth who is more dear to me.

Original: 18.70 And he who will study this sacred dialogue of ours, by him I shall have been worshipped by the sacrifice of wisdom,  such is My conviction.
Translated: 18.70. The man who will read this religious dialogue between us will be worshipped by the sage - that is my opinion.

Original: 18.71 Also the man who hears this, full of faith and free from malice, he, too, liberated, shall attain to the happy worlds of those of righteous deeds.
Translated: And whoever is a believer and a man of understanding, and he who listens to it, he will be absolved of his sins and will be accepted into a people of virtuous people.

Original: 18.72 Has this been heard, O Arjuna, with one-pointed mind? Has the delusion of thy ignorance been destroyed, O Dhananjaya?
Translated: O Parth, have you listened to it with your heart? O Dhanjanja, has your ignorance vanished?

Original: 18.73 Arjuna said  Destroyed is my delusion as I have gained my knowledge (memory) through Thy grace, O Krishna. I remain freed from doubts. I will act according to Thy word.
Translated: 18.73. Arjuna said: O Achyut, by your grace my charm has been destroyed, and I have received memory. Now I am unshakable and I will obey your word.

Original: 18.74 Sanjaya said  Thus I have heard this wonderful dialogue between Krishna and the high-souled Arjuna, which causes the hair to stand on end.
Translated: 18.74 . Sanjay said -- so I described this wonderful and exciting dialogue between Lord Vasudev and Mahatma Arjuna.

Original: 18.75 Through the grace of Vyasa I have heard this supreme and most secret Yoga direct from Krishna, the Lord of Yoga, Himself declaring it.
Translated: 18.75 By the grace of Vyas Ji, I heard Lord Krishna himself speaking this sacred yoga.

Original: 18.76 O King, remembering this wonderful and holy dialogue between Krishna and Arjuna, I rejoice again and again.
Translated: 18.76 O Rajen, I am again and again happy to recall this wonderful and sacred dialogue between Lord Keshav and Arjuna.

Original: 18.77 And, remembering again and again, also that most wonderful form of Hari, great is my wonder, O King; and I rejoice again and again.
Translated: O Rajan, I am greatly surprised and rejoiced to recall the wonderful form of Sri Hari.

Original: 18.78 Wherever is Krishna, the Lord of Yoga; wherever is Arjuna, the wielder of the bow; there are prosperity, victory, happiness and firm policy; such is my conviction.
Translated: 18.78 Where Yogeshwar Sri Krishna is and where Arjuna is the archer, there is Sri, Vijay, Vibhuthi and Poor politics, I think.
